help.guidance: When identifying citations, look for author names and dates in parentheses or superscript numbers referring to footnotes.
References typically appear at the end of the document and contain full bibliographic information.
Captions are usually found directly above or below figures, tables, or images.
Pay attention to formatting cues: italics, quotation marks, and indentation often indicate specific element types.
If you're unsure about the citation style, look for clues in the overall document format or any style guide mentions.
Remember that some elements, like equations or block quotes, may have distinct formatting or placement within the text.
When extracting elements, include all relevant information (e.g., for citations, capture both the in-text citation and its corresponding reference entry).
If you encounter an element that doesn't fit the predefined categories, describe it as best you can and note its unique characteristics.
When identifying headings and sections, pay attention to font size, weight, and styling to determine their hierarchical level.
Look for structural elements like the table of contents, abstract, and keywords, which are often found at the beginning of a document.
When extracting paragraphs, note their relationship to surrounding headings and sections.
For documents with complex structures, create a mental outline to help understand the relationships between different elements.
